No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

One of my favorite restaurants I've been to in some time. My friend, who has been to the location in Miami, ordered for our group of three. Everything we had was amazing, the service was phenomenal, and the ambiance / high ceilings were very cool. We had the short ribs, duck, pork buns, fried rice, and crispy rice sushi. Every single thing we had was great.

Love this place! The Miami location is one of my favorite restaurants so I was so excited they opened in NYC! Although the pride of the roasted cauliflower went way up and they don't do the tasting menu here but hey that's NY for ya.  Came here for happy hour and Max was our server, such a wonderful experience! Blown away by the Krispy kale! Will definitely be back for brunch!

Came here on a Tuesday night and it was a full house! The food was delicious! We started off with the tuna crispy rice (must have).. then we had the soft shell crab- I felt it was a bit fishy and I would pass on that. The sweet potato was absolutely delicious and so was the grilled octopus and fried chicken! I took a star off due to the drink menu. I ordered a "pink puppy" which is their version of a lychee martini.... Did not enjoy it at all! I should of just stuck with wine from the start. Other than that the food was amazing and the service was top notch. I highly recommend coming here. And I look forward to coming back!
No comment

AMAZING spot downtown. If you've been to any trendy Asian restaurant in Miami, it's really giving that. Seems small from the front, but once you're taken to the back to get seated, you are surprised with a huge dining room and extremely high ceilings. Music and vibes are on par. 4 friends and I went and split a bunch of apps and entrees. We ordered the chickpea sushi (10/10), tuna crispy rice (8.5/10), crispy crab crispy rice (8.5/10), corn (7/10 - on the cob was hard to split), head of cauliflower (9/10 - sauce was excellent), chicories salad (10/10). Overall everything was great. 3 of us ordered the Snowbird cocktails, small and dainty but packed with a punch. We will definitely be returning soon.

I came here regardless of the mix reviews because the Miami location is fantastic. Ok so the aesthetics and vibes are definitely New York energy, music is great ( a bit loud in case that may bother you). However drinks are a bit overpriced and lacking presentation. The food overall is good but I wouldn't say the best Asian food I have had. The highlight for me was the short rib, it came right off the bone and was paired with different sauces. The tuna crispy rice was a bit bland for our liking. The soft shell crab were tasty but very tiny. The octopus was tasty and fresh, the ceviche sauce is different than what you would normally have in a ceviche. The fried chicken were crispy and huge, I would have liked more flavor ! (Very sharable) Overall, if you want to treat yourself to a nice ambiance, great service and expensive food go here !

This place is always packed and also packed with flavor! I love every dish its so thought out and hits every note! The sides are even the stars especially the yam, the corn, and the shishitos with a flavorful sauce. The service was a bit slow but they were busy. I come back time and time again for the crispy rice!!
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

Kyu leaves a great impression with their delicious foods and cocktails. The ambiance is definitely NYC chic. I really enjoyed their Crispy Tuna Rice, different from many I have tried. The dishes come out as they are ready so do not expect for all orders to come out at the same time. The short rib and duck was phenomenal.
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

Ambiance definitely WOWED me, very elegant. The food was amazingly delicious, especially their signature dish the cauliflower was different, but delicious. Please keep in mind the cauliflower is pretty huge. The staff are very attentive. Your table is cleaned if it's messy after a meal. A box of Utensils are on your table, but I must add this and I really don't like doing this, however please be aware of waitress Natalia. She was stand-offish and rude. I ordered a second drink different from the first and did not like it and  Natalia's response was, "What's wrong with your drink now"! Then she left the drink there and walked away leaving me confused. I was expecting the usual response from waitstaff, I apologize would you like another drink, etc... other than that KYU is highly recommended. It is a bit $$$
No comment
No comment
No comment

Kyu has come to New York and it is definitely the new spot for birthday celebrations or just getting together with friends. The space formerly housed Bobby Flay's Gato which closed during the Pandemic. It has been completely redone with a beautiful bar upfront. The service is very good but a bit impersonal. The menu is also good with some interesting items. The cocktails are also very good. None of the individual elements matter as much as the whole, Kyu is meant to be a spot to get together with friends for a celebration. It certainly achieves that. Well done.
No comment

Very expensive dinner but enjoyed some of the entrees a lot. Favorites of the night was the crispy flavorful fried rice, tender ribs and delicious potstickers. I would skip the bone marrow (too meaty and did not enjoy the texture that much) and order only 1 of the fried chicken ( very large chicken pieces, felt heavy). The dessert pineapple bread was light and airy. Cocktails were great all around. Don't let the staff pressure you into over ordering - add as you go along to avoid having too many leftovers.
No comment

2 stars only for the ambiance. Waitress barely remembers our drink orders. Foods are extremely disappointing. Tuna Crispy Rice is way to sticky and fish was warm and bland. Crab bun was salty. Tomahawk was dry as paper. Duck fried rice had no grain texture yet raw egg york was overpowering. Not coming back
No comment
No comment
Ok, it's overpriced AF, but it sure feels like Miami in NYC, down to the clientele. The food took forever to come out, but everything was delicious.
No comment
No comment

This was great, albeit very, very expensive. First visit, we got the tuna on crispy rice, the cauliflower, the Japanese sweet potato, the stone pot fried rice with duck, the lamb saddle, and the s'mores cake. There wasn't anything we didn't like, but our single favorite dish was the lamb saddle, and I'm not sure there's anything that would be a must for next time -- as great as the lamb saddle was, there are other items on the smoked menu that looked great as well. On the downside, everything was very expensive and extremely heavy -- we were told that three dishes per person would be a good amount of food, but we probably could have stopped before the lamb saddle and dessert and been full.
Couldn't recommend this restaurant enough. Amazing staff and overall very high-quality food. The short rib is to die for as are some of the crispy rice options.
No comment
No comment
No comment

Stellar! The food was delicious and the service was friendly and helpful, as I am very indecisive sometimes lol. Will definitely be back. I suggest the kimchi rice and the steak (definitely to share!)

I don't understand all the hateration holleration in this review section, but I'm here to say Kyu was an excellent experience. My table had the soft shell crab buns, crispy rice (duh!), sweet potato, short ribs, pan fried dumplings and a bottle of fine sake. The sweet potato truly stole the show, but each dish had their own unique profile and were tasty. The service was extremely attentive and polite. Perfect vibe with a great playlist.
Highly recommend the tuna crispy rice, the cauliflower, the crab fried rice, and the burrata. Would give 5 stars if the pricing was 25-30% cheaper than listed.
Nice setting but every dish was super mid - definitely not worth the price. We got the brisket, cauliflower, and hamachi crispy rice - none of them stood out.

This place has a nice upscale calm vibe and a good music playlist with a balance of hip hop and other songs. i had the Hamachi slices which were so delicious the sushi tastes so fresh it was delicious. I had coconut cream spinach I didn't like that too much at and was charged $35 for a Lemon drop with Hendrix which i felt like was hwy robbery. The highlight of the evening was definite the Beef ribs they melt in your mouth it was soo good omg I would definitely go back for the ribs and Hamachi slices and I hear the chicken is good so maybe i'll try that but definitely won't be drinking from this place anymore

Copy paste Miami to New York - nothing out of the ordinary. Service could be better, but understandably the restaurant just opened so I'm sure they're just figuring things out. The Thai fried rice/brisket is a must, and the cocktail menu does not disappoint. I appreciate the owner and chef walking around shaking hands - that shows true hospitality. Great location - if you're coming here then chances are you'll run into someone you know. I did not book a reservation online and called to check for availability and it was no issue. I would definitely come back.
No comment

Amazing experience! Everything at KYU (pronounced "-cue" was just fantastic! Great comfortable atmosphere with very nice decor. Chef Chris A. absolutely delivers!! Service is amazing and prompt! Cocktails are delicious. Must try the Wagyu toast! Short ribs were phenomenal as well! We personally loved everything we ordered here. Plenty of variety on the menu as well. They are also very quick to respond to reservations via email and were able to squeeze us in on a very busy Saturday night. Can't wait to be back! Keep up the great work! Already craving some of the food I had there!!

The food here was very good! The bone marrow was beyond amazing and highly suggest it! Beware if you order extra bread they will charge you for it. The tuna and the hamachi were so fresh and flavorful. I also had the wabi Sabi sour cocktail with the egg white and it was very tasty. A perfect start to the meal! I will definitely be back and I will request Pedro and Meagan . They were such an awesome server team!

Vibes and ambiance are great, service is great! Drinks are really good!! Food is okay at best. The fried chicken was good. Everything else was not. I'd go back for just drinks cus it really is a vibe in there!

Dined here for a friend's Birthday Brunch. The restaurant is quite easy to get to via car or subway. The aesthetic of this place is inviting and classy. I love the open concept kitchen along with the gorgeous centralized Bar. The cocktail menu is diverse along with several selections for Brunch. The menu has recently opened for brunch. The selections were really healthy and severed tapas style - though I do with there was more variety. I do however think that the selection is kept this way to keep with demand and ensure diners are served promptly just as we were. I will say that the selections are rather pricey which is in hand for the location and namesake. All in all, it was a good experience. The bartenders and servers were nothing but perfect and ensured we were comfortable and full. They provided suggestions and our cups were never empty - Much kudos goes out to them!
Great food, ambiance, and service. Can't find food like this anywhere else in NYC. The experience was great.

Ambiance and service is A1.   Food needs substantial work. Duck fat fried rice is so watered down it should be labeled as congee.  The duck is dry and has zero flavor. Presentation was good though.  Short rib is over cooked. Fried chicken - don't get it if you're expecting Korean fried chicken.  Cauliflower is why this has 2 stars

i've been to the miami location & was excited for the nyc location! we had a holiday dinner and it did not disappoint-a group of 6 of us shared the tuna crispy rice, hamachi crispy rice, fried rice with crab, cauliflower, shishito peppers with a cheeto like topping, the short rib, the corn, the korean fried chicken & coconut cake and ice cream!! what a meal!! definitely will be back!

We were really looking forward to this new restaurant as a neighbor and hoped to be regulars . The good news is the fried chicken did live up to expectations , crispy and flavorful . The roasted Cauliflower also excellent . Our mezcal drink which had a few interesting ingredients just tasted like straight mezcal . But the reason it gets a 3 is the Pork  Belly in the pork bun actually tasted rotten  , no other way to explain it ( and we have had this dish in many restaurants & never had any issues) . Plus with prices like $35 for  Cauliflower  you expect good service. So when when its sent back uneaten and you explain why . I was shocked to see  later nothing was done for us on the check . Disappointing

Absolutely incredible .  I went to the one in Miami and that one didn't disappoint as well.  The bone marrow ....wow....the pork belly buns....wow.....the beef tenderloin was ok(a little tough) ....if you get any of the rice bowls, keep in mind , they're very large, so if you plan on eating a lot, try to steer away from this item.  This place is phenomenal.  Make rezzy's well in advance though....I'll be baaaaaaccckkkk
No comment
No comment

What an overrated, tacky place. Food was incredibly salty, small portions. Our waiter completely scammed us, was more of a salesman trying to sell the most expensive dishes. Plates were tiny. Extremely expensive. Would not go back

Already as tough a rez as Miami, but doesn't measure up.  We ordered at 6:30, 2 apps one entree and drinks.  Drink came in 10 minutes.  All the food,ALL the food came 5 minutes later.  Talk about rushed.  This place is pricey. To have a $150 meal finish in a half hour is not okay.  Cleared our plates while there was still some food. Yes, it's opening weekend. Hopefully they learn how to pace and space out a meal.  Noise level is a 9/10. Way too loud.  Tables are close, place is all steel and nothing to absorb the sound.  Not sure that can be fixed.  Food was good.  Best dish was the Thai hot stone rice.  Fried chicken was a bit dry, red pepper sauce too spicy.  Heavy hand with the wasabi on the pressed rice sushi.  Didn't eat dessert because the noise was really getting to us.  The only reason to go back would be for the stone pot rice.

I ordered a tofu roll and ended up with a pork roll instead. I'm a vegan and have been for years. When I asked for a manager they did absolutely nothing about it and was very rude about the entire situation. The food wasn't even good. Only getting one star because the bartender was super nice and the drinks were great.

Service is okay but cocktails and food is pretty good I won't lie. I don't like veggies but the cauliflower was really good. The stand out dish for me was the short rib if you like meat Fall off the bone type stuff

Food was excellent! Service not so much. They took about 45 minutes to bring me a drink I asked for and the waiters seemed very aloof. They wouldn't let us sit in the main dining room as my reservation was made day of, although I saw plenty of open seats. If you go I'd say enjoy the food but prepare for very slow bare bones service. This doesn't compare to the one in Miami unfortunately

Some things here were good but too expensive for what it was. I had the wagyu toast which had too much going on and was way overpriced, also the tuna crispy rice which was good but I've had better elsewhere for less than half of the price. It was my friend's birthday and they didn't do anything for us. Just an average experience

As one who travels to Miami a few times a year, I always looked forward to going  to my favorite restaurant down there - Kyu.  I'd recommend it to all my friends who visited there and pleaded with the staff to open a NYC location. Well, prayers do get answered. And they hit it out of the park. I went there last night and had a blast. It started with the wonderful staff that greeted us upon arrival - 4 beautiful ladies all smiling and very welcoming. The setup is similar to Miami with the wonderful open kitchen. I was delighted to see so many of my favorites on the menu like the fabulous roasted cauliflower - a must have. We ordered the Tuna Crispy Rice and the Hamachi Crispy Rice which were my two favorite dishes of the night. The wagyu toast was yummy with just the right amount of truffle purée. The sliced Hamachi with white ponzu, mint, and basil was absolutely amazing. The Korean Fried chicken was really good, but not as good as I had remembered it being in Miami. While I also preferred the delicious red snapper in Miami, the halibut was a great runner up and enjoyed by everyone at our table. Pedro, our waiter, was charming and funny and totally on the ball. He had the food sent out to us at just the right pace. Bethany, the manager, was also very sweet and accommodating. Since we were doing more veggies and seafood last night, I cannot wait to go back for the stone pot Thai Fried Rice with Duck and the short ribs. Great job Kyu, New York. I will be back again soon.

The ambiance is very nice as were the first three courses. However the entree we ordered, the lamb saddle came out cold the first time. Upon sending it back it returned as the saltiest piece of food I've ever eaten. It totally ruined the experience.

The sweet potato was amazing! The cauliflower and fried chicken were very good as well. For dessert we had the breaded cake- it was okay- I got the coconut cake which was very good, but had too take home since the dessert portions are definitely for 2+ people.

Chef Chris was amazing!!!!!! We went for a special event for my son and Chef Chris spoiled us! He was so kind and visited our table multiple times. Our server Aileen was phenomenal!!! Every dish was delicious as well. We really loved the fried chicken, Burrata, cauliflower, and the tuna crispy rice. We came all the way from california for this place.

I am here now. Place is Terrible. Food was beyond horrible. Avocado salad tasted like you were eating flowers. We sent it back. Gyoza tasted like it had hot dog meat inside. Bone marrow, they ruined it with all the stuff on top. Brisket, gross.
delicious, loved the crispy rice, really nice waitstaff! but i will say one thing - the vibe? evil cheesecake factory. in a good way! come on down everyone to new york's hottest new restaurant!!!!
Delicious food, very creative and inspired! Highly recommend the raging geisha, Korean fried chicken, and stone pot!

We absolutely loved KYU NYC. The restaurant came recommended to us by my husband's friend and client. We took Tenzen's suggestion and ordered 4 appetizers, two entrees, a rice dish and a vegetable which was perfect. The crisp pork belly buns were delicious. The sliced hamachi melted in our mouths. The roasted cauliflower was so good that we could have licked the plate it was on. The tuna crispy rice was just okay (I say this because it wasn't special versus the other dishes and we've had this at other restaurants in the past.) The entrees were amazing -- wagu beef brisket in lettuce wraps and the duck breast burnt ends. We were huge fans of the king crab stone pot thai fried rice and the baby bok choy with toasted garlic. It was my son's birthday so we ordered a couple of desserts which were fabulous (dark chocolate s'mores cake and soaked milk bread) and they also brought an extra dessert with an eatable cake candle, too. Oh - I can't forget the pink puppy cocktail (their version of a lychee martini.) So good. I would highly recommend and look forward to going back!
Great experience and great food. This restaurant is most def one of my NYC fav spots. Cocktails are so delicate and thought out and the hospitality blew me out of the water. 10/10

I live in the neighborhood and waited until the initial hype settled down. Went to the bar ordered 2 martinis 2 appetizers and a glass of wine. Asked for shishito peppers they initially said yes but then said you can't have it's on the main menu not the bar snack menu. Let's just say shishito peppers should be on every bar menu. Ordered pork bun and crispy rice app. Pork Buns were average. I could get the same thing in Chinatown for $4. The crispy rice came after I finished my $30 Martini . Asked for one olive and came with 2. It's a $30 Martini get it right . My friend ordered a Gin Martini. Came with too much vermouth . Told the bartender that . He said sorry.I guess no fixing drinks here .After the rice came the bill was $144. 2 small apps and 3 drinks. After a few weeks it didn't seem as packed and the Local NoHo didn't seem present. Hope they fix things quick. The atmosphere is great. The bar had an unimpressive selection of what is expected in the neighborhood. Unless things change it's a very nice Panda Express with overpriced Martinis.

Tried their hojicha latte and that was probably the best hojicha latte that I have ever tried! The tea quality was very high and I like how they have a few vegan milk options, including a homemade coconut milk. Even though I wanted to try the coconut milk, I picked oat milk since the coconut flavor from coconut milk might overshadow the tea itself. I don't think the drink was sweetened but there was some natural sweetness coming from the oat milk, which complemented the tea very well. Didn't try any of their cookies or desserts but definitely would love to come back and try them in the future!

Cozy authentic Japanese tea and matcha! It's great when not crowded and the environment feels so warm. I got iced matcha latte and it was really really good. You can tell they put quality time and care into making it. Excited to come back!

Greens tea cafe. If you are looking for authentic Japanese green tea experience, stop by one of their stores in NyC. I stopped by the location in Greenpoint. Entering, space is bright, clean and minimalistic. Walls of variety of Japanese green tea from various regions of Japan, to purchase. You can order tea for stay experience or Togo. Try also have variety of matcha desserts on menu. Definitely a must stop for some zen moments.
No comment
No comment

One of my favorite businesses in NYC! This place is SERIOUS about their matcha, and it literally changed how I drink it - before I came here, I added sugar to my matcha daily. After tasting the complexity of flavor in a single matcha latte at Kettl, I bought the bulk size and haven't added sugar since! Their desserts are also just phenomenal - go all in and get the matcha parfait, it's worth it. Their soba cha latte is also really good, super unique and nutty and tastes beautifully sweet without any added sugar. They have a couple other smaller locations, but this is the only one with the full dessert menu and a beautiful selection of ceramics as well.
No comment

Great place for some high quality Matcha and beautiful pottery. I went here for a tasting. The staff and owner is very knowledgeable. The pots, cups and vases are simply amazing. The Soba latte was very good. The cookies are also delicious. A must visit.

Very cute place for matcha and other tea related desserts and cookies. The cookies were probably my favorite because they' were lightly sweet and come in different tea flavors. Ironically, we got matcha lattes and hojicha lattes to stay...and ended up being served to go cups even tho they have full displays of various tea cups and matcha bowls. There's a big table in the middle and a bar in the back. There's even a matcha grinder that was on and grinding green tea powder
No comment
No comment

A friend had gifted me one of Kettl's boxed sets for Christmas & after finally opening the bag of homemade matcha chocolate bar, I knew I had to make a stop here. While browsing in the city, I could've stopped at the Bowery location but I knew I wanted to see the store. Hence, I made the trek to Greenpoint & I'm so glad I did. Once I walked into the store, I knew I was walking into matcha heaven. The store/tea room looked pristine, with the sunlight naturally lighting up the room. Of course, I'll be returning for a tea tasting but for today, I needed to satisfy my need for more matcha chocolate. Rich, velvety & full of matcha filled each bite and I wanted to buy some to share. I might've gone overboard possibly buying a little too many, but trust me, they're worth every penny!

Amazing tea place with hard to find leaves. My favorite is the iribancha, which I haven't been able to find anywhere else. My friend and I ordered a brewed cup to go, but I strongly suspect that they provided the wrong tea (ordered: iribancha, received: green tea).

Nice place but with limited seating. A good spot for quick catch-up but def not the place if u wanna spend an hour with.  A good selection of teas but desserts are a bit disappointing (aka too sweet). Will return for to-go drink.

Stopped by and tried the matcha and sobacha lattes - both were really good. The sobacha latte convinced me to buy a 200g pack of sobacha to make at home. When we checked out at the register, the cashier very helpfully offered us instructions on how to brew it as a tea and a latte (thank you!).

After visiting their Bowery location, I wanted to check out their original Greenpoint location to try their matcha-flavored sweets. I got the hojicha cookie and the matcha chocolate with soba crunch. The hojicha cookie (I ate it all before I could take a picture woops!) had a strong hojicha flavor and the cookie was soft and chewy. The matcha soba crunch chocolate was amazing! The chocolate had a strong matcha flavor and the soba crunch was still crisp and added a savory, roasted flavor that worked so well with the matcha. I'm obsessed with the soba cha now and I want to try everything soba cha related now! Their sweets are definitely on the pricey side. The cookie was $5 and the chocolate was $10 ;_; but honestly, they were so good, I would definitely get them again!

I absolutely love tea and was excited to try this place. It's a very cute shop and they have tons of diff tea leaves for purchase. We got the gyokuro which was underwhelming and didn't have much flavor and felt overpriced.

Japanese tea house in Greenpoin Brooklyn. It's truly Matcha green tea house it's huge choice of tea and everything for tea. Green tea soft serve that amazing and cookies to accompany with your tea. Big choice of gift items.

An amazing space for peace and quiet. My matcha tea was delicious too. I was skeptical of the cost but to recharge in the space was worth it.
Reliable and consistently great matcha. The soba cookie is so addicting. My only gripe is I wish they opened earlier so I could make it my morning matcha spot :(

Dhamaka is serving up the most authentic and delicious Rajasthani food in the city, if not in the country. It's certainly not for the spice-intolerant, but for those of you who appreciate some heat, it's an absolute must-try. Our waiter was incredibly kind and made some great recommendations, including the goat neck biryani (the highlight of the meal), the chicken pulao, and the beguni, all of which were a 10/10. We were also lucky enough to be seated indoors, and the ambience of the restaurant is great. If you can manage to snag a recommendation, don't give it up!

column3: Upper East Side, New York, NY
column6: If you're vegetarian I'm already going to warn you that you're probably going to be disappointed. I was so excited when I finally was able to get a reservation here but there are 3 vegetarian options only 1 of which is an actual entree. I got the papdi chaat which was an appetizer and I was not happy with it. The papdi wasn't even papdi, it had this weird crumbly texture and it was just not the move. I also asked them if they could make it without the chili powder on top because I can't eat spicy and they made such a big deal about? The only veg entree is paneer methi and I wasn't about to pay $30 for spinach paneer.
Place has horrible tasting food . Highly over rated. Food is overcooked and dry and overpriced. Was really disappointed with my experience here

3.5 stars - Dhamaka requires a reservation a few weeks (almost a month) in advance. I really wanted to try Dhamaka because of all the hype it's gotten in the media and press. There is indoor seating and outdoor seating within a covered tent on the street. I recommend trying as many of the appetizers as possible - I thought these were the yummiest things on the menu! The portions are fairly small but good for sharing if you want to try many things on the menu. I found the food to be pretty spicy but still enjoyed it.

SO good. They don't mess around with the spice level here so come ready. The yogurt side they serve with the biryani is the perfect palate cleanser to neutralize the heat. Our waitress was excellent and recommended us the goat neck biryani and the paneer - both options are amazing. The biryani is pretty spicy for me, but not to the point where the numbness overwhelms the flavor. I was a big fan of the paneer too, which was super bouncy and flavorful.

Apprently this place is so hard to get reservations for. My friend has been trying to get a spot since last year and he finally found a spot for us to go. It was a last minute Decision to go, and I was so hyped because apparently this place was rated the best restaurant in America. As a desi American, you can a imagine my excitement. However, when I got there. Service was AMAZING, but the food was just mid. The paneer was good, everything was just good. Some of the dishes I didn't like to be honest, but when we ate the left overs I liked them better the next day.  The masala sat nicely the next day. I wouldn't go out of my way to go there and wouldn't recommend!

I had the champaran meat which was super tender and flavorful. I expected it to be spicer but still was delish. The ragda pattice was my favorite dish of the night. Very flavorful and good spice. Next time I'm getting the goat biryani for sure - it looked amazing.

We tried the goats neck biryani, the lasooni prawn, the ajwani paneer tikka, and the papdi chaat. Of the items we ordered my favorite was the papdi chaat, though I do wish it came with something to dip in it rather than us having to order that for a separate charge. I thought the paneer was a bit dry and the goat neck biryani was good but too spicy for me to eat much of.

Oh man...definitely the best paneer I've had. My whole experience at this place was awesome. My friends and I didn't have a reservation, but the host was so accommodating and made room for us! In the meantime, there was great Bollywood music playing and we danced while drinking great Indian beer (the glass was so cute too). The aloo chat appetizer was solid, but the paneer was the star. The texture was perfect - most other places make it too hard - and the flavors were nice and spicy, but not too salty or heavy. On the pricier side, but definitely worth it, and the quantity is very large.

Lot of Hype and publicity for this place and we had an occasion to go to and I booked a table a month in advance and was eagerly waiting to enjoy some good food..... unfortunately it was a major disappointment.... The food was pedantic, greasy and down right bad. Doesn't deserve a Michelin 3 stars.

I finally secured a reservation after a long wait and the place did not disappoint. We got the goat neck biryani (duh) and a day special which was a grilled Himalayan rainbow trout. The grilled trout was the highlight of our evening. It was spiced and grilled to perfection. The biryani was great but if I  were to compare it to the biryani I had at Semma and the lamb biryani I once had at Adda that I can't seem to find again.. it slightly pales in comparison. Nevertheless it is a great restaurant to try and I will be back again to try the chicken pulao that's served in a pressure cooker!!!

The goat neck biryani was awesome too and the must-order, but note there are a lot of bones and a bit too spicy for me. Had stomach issues later on too with all the spices.

We were able to get reservations last minute and it was definitely worth it. The restaurant is located inside a market and has a chill vibe. I loved all the vegetarian items on the menu under snacks and grill. The ajwain paneer was so soft and fresh. The food is spicy. Lots of creative cocktails and mocktails. I wasn't a fan of the entree methi paneer as it tasted too bitter. The pulav was ok too. I would just go for the appetizers again.
No comment

Found in Essex market, you wouldn't know that this is one of the best NYC restaurants until you see the food coming out. We waited to get a reservation here for a few months and it was worth the wait. The whole experience was top notch including the service and the food. While there are a number of more adventurous options on the menu, we stuck with the Tabak maaz (lamb ribs) , chicken pressure cooker pulao and panner methi. Keep in mind that everything was on the spicier side, but the flavors were incredible and not like other Indian food that I've had before. The tabak maaz was out of this world and definitely our favorite thing. We will happily be coming back!

Service is excellent although the waitress did drop a couple items when she was clearing the table. I don't know why people say the food here is so spicy. I don't think it is. The eggplant appetizer was outstanding. I just loved licking my fingers with the spice seasoning, the lamb chops are phenomenal. But extremely fatty I had the garlic ghost dish which people rave about. I thought it was OK. Didn't have tremendous flavor, was not that spicy at all, had a lot of bone and not so much meat, and was very oily. The paratha was very disappointing. Very oily, and very flaky. Definitely over cooked. I would come back to try the fry pomfret and the goat testicles appetizer which is supposedly phenomenal. The bhel puri is phenomenal by the way.  I had that the first time I was here I thought the goat biryani was very good. Huge portion. And pricey at $43.
No comment

We're long time fans of Adda and Semma, so were delighted when we finally succeeded in reserving a table at Dhamaka. Perhaps our expectations were too high, but our meal was disappointing. Nothing was bad, everything was all quite good, it just wasn't great. And after years of hype, months of trying to book a table, not to mention $400+ for four people, the fact that it was merely good was a big let down.

The food was amazing! I can't remember exactly what I had but they don't play. The spice is real. The food is actually spicy but also well flavored. The ambiance of the place is colorful, vibrant and fun.
Dhamaka is one of our favorite restaurant in lower east side and NY! Is 100% recommended, food is AMAZiNG, service is great they are all so nice and helpful, and the place is super pretty.
Great food and ambiance. Loved the drinks that complimented their menu. We had the biriyani and paneer and chaat. All amazing.

This place is a must try progressive Indian restaurant. Since it is a family style restaurant, I recommend coming with a medium to large sized party so that you can split as many shared plates as possible - definitely a bang for your buck this way. My group started with the papdi chaat, which was a total flavor bomb of sweet, savory, and spicy. Then came the tabak maaz (lamb ribs) that were so tender they fell off the bone. For the main course we had goat neck dum biriyani (my favorite), paneer methi, and dal dhamaka with a side of roti and rice. Every item we ate was a hit, so you can't go wrong. Next time I want to be more adventurous and try the baby shark on the menu :0

This place , if you can get in, is worth it.  Better for a group of 4+.  Try as many things as you can.  Expect to be full/have leftovers after.

this food here is extremely spicy! would only come if you're prepared for a ton of spice and oil. totally understand that indian food is spicy, but this was to the point of it overpowering the flavor and weakening the experience! only dishes i can recommend are the dish appetizer (thought very fried) and the paneer methi. was able to get a res through Resy waitlist. service was also super mid - guy was not helpful and just seemed annoyed. was really looking forward to this place and all of us were pretty disappointed :(

A fantastic time at Dhamaka.Drinkd and food on point- but the food is spicy - be warned. Unapologetic Indian food!!!!

Incredible flavors and loved the originality of the dishes. I particularly loved the lamb ribs and stuffed peppers but the famous biryani is also really worth the try! Definitely more of a relaxed and laid back ambiance with a bustling atmosphere and located in the Essex Market.

The staff was OUTSTANDING. Seriously every single staff member was friendly and attentive. Outdoor patio seating was warm even in 15 degree weather. Delicious mixed drinks. All of the food was decent- not too spicy- but nothing special. The portions were HUGE in my opinion, so consider splitting an entree. The standouts were the delicious lamb appetizer and ridiculously good flaky bread. Also the rice is above average. The reason for 3 stars is that I think everything was overpriced. It's a nice atmosphere for date night but if you just want some yummy Indian food you may as well go somewhere cheaper.

The food here is very good and very spicy.  The paneer is outstanding, fish and chicken dishes are good (though the chicken dish is low on meat and high on bones).  The paratha was good, it is thin though a bit greasy.   Service is good.  Atmosphere could use an upgrade, though the setting suits market food.

Excellent albeit slightly more expensive sister restaurant to Queens,  Adda. If you are just in it for the biryani I would go to Queens. The reason to come would be the Lamb Shank Nihari, so good we took the sauce home, other highlights were the Paplet Fry, and of course the Goat Neck Dum Biryani. The dessert of a take on Basque cheesecake was inventive but not exciting.

The food was meh. We had the vegetarian dishes which were nothing special. We were sat next to the restroom, which is gross and annoying. They couldn't accommodate moving. Pretty much paid $200 to eat s@#*... literally. Skip this place. There are other great options in the city.

Food was too spicy, service was bad. Hype isn't real. The wait staff to table ratio was too high.

I cannot believe I haven't reviewed this place! I first came here almost exactly one year ago and have basically been their unofficial ambassador (will you hire me UA? ). To anyone and everyone who will listen, I urge them to come here ASAP. Their biryani is THE BEST in the city (my family's from Hyderabad, where the dish originated, so trust me when I say I know a good biryani). Right amount of spicy while still being so delicious. I'm so upset that I just realized I haven't reviewed this place cause I can't even remember all the dishes I tried. But off the top of my head, get the paneer (appetizer), okra, and the biryani! You won't be disappointed. Can't wait to come back!!

Came here with a couple visiting out of town friends who had heard about the place. For apps we got the prawn, paneer tikka, bharela marcha, and the beguni. For the main course we got the goat neck biryani. Service was friendly and all of the food was good, but I don't really think it was good enough to deserve the price point. Just seems like another "trendy" Instagram hyped up place that people go to just to say they went there. You can get just as tasty food at plenty of other spots in the city for a much more reasonable price. For homemade paneer and out of the world biryani you're much better off going to Angel in Jackson Heights. Thank me later :)

This is probably the best Indian restaurant I have ever encountered in my life . Everythjng was sensational . Please please please go !

We were lucky enough to score an early dinner reservation on a Saturday evening at Dhamaka, which is located in Essex Market. The atmosphere was quite lively and service was very friendly and attentive. Our server helped us with a couple of suggestions to complete our order and we ended up ordering the right amount of food for the three of us. First were the Ajwani Paneer Tikka, Papdi Chaat, and Paplet Fry. For the main entrees we ordered the Lamb Shank, which was a special that night, the famous Goat Neck Dum Biryani and some Paratha on the side. It was all a great combination, very flavorful. The lamb was super tender. We were excited to try dishes other than the ones we would usually order at an Indian restaurant. We also ordered some drinks, including the Passionfruit Mango Lassi, which was soothing considering the level of heat in some of the dishes. I would definitely recommend coming here for a great experience!

Food was great overall - recommend the biriyani and the the palak paneer was incredible. The downside was the rest of the dishes were not worthy

This place is just unbelievable. I been trying to make reservations for 3 months and every time there is a glitch in the system. Their is no phone number to call. I been trying to make reservations and it just doesn't happen. What kind of place only has reservations through resy. Their app is also faulty. Not meant to be.

Dhamaka was amazing! It exceeded our expectations and chef chintan was sooo sweet! We loved the chaat papdi and loved the pomegranates added in!! The paneer tikka was *chefs kiss*! Like we finished that in 50 seconds. Gurda kapoora(goat kidney and testicles) was probably the best thing we tried! And the goat neck biryani was the best biryani I've ever had. Cannot wait to go back

The sole feature you need to know is that it's in demand. It's an awful experience. Guests are overbooked and then repeatedly told throughout the meal that they are on a tight schedule - 1 hour and 15 minutes per table. You are treated very rudely, over and over again, in the name of moving people through the dining process. It would be faster if the menu weren't bizarrely incomprehensible (e.g. the "Grill" section is actually what would be labeled appetizers or starters on any other menu, and the "Snacks" are not described with their ingredients, so the server says things like, "This is the cold one!" and has to go ask the kitchen to answer the question, "what is the crunchy stuff this dish is made of?"). Main dishes take forever to come out, even though there are only a few options available that are mostly long braises. Food is served in the pots they are cooked in (like a crappy aluminum pressure cooker, not a charming bit of stoneware). The food is OK, but sloppy. Some of it is so spicy that the servers explain this is why they wear shirts that say "Unapologetically Indian," but I like spice, and this was just lazy cooking. Our chicken biryani had two disgusting chunks of hacked-up dark meat on the bone, with little chards of small, sharp bones, large curry leaves, and clumps of gristle strewn throughout the dish. The paratha was greasy, chewy, and flavorless. The paneer app was ok. The raita was watery and bland. Mainly, though, it's a very poorly run business. You are constantly hounded about time from the moment you arrive. You are told you can't add anything to your order after you pick a main dish because they take 30-40 minutes to make, and then you are warned again before you finish eating your main that you need to order a dessert if you want one because they take a long time to prepare. We were asked to leave our table less than one minute after we paid our bill to allow another party to sit. The restaurant's overall rudeness and absurd inability to time out basic, rustic food make the prices ($40 mains, $20 "snacks") laughable. This place is a mess, and it's exploiting some popularity to generate a false sense of demand through rushing the reservations, cutting corners in the kitchen, and deliberately abusing diners with policies that keep you from enjoying the truly mediocre food. I gave it an extra star because the paneer appetizer was pretty good (not outstanding) and our waiter was sweet, if inept.

Food was not tasty, overpriced, poor customer service, and the outdoor area...Instead of losing some business since their heater had been broken for half the patio, they chose to keep reservations for tables outside & people getting sick in 22 degree weather (although reservations were made a month prior)

Explosive flavors and certainly unapologetic Indian! We ordered an array of starters and grill items and each one unique in its own way but the chaat really stood out amongst the meaty selections! We moved into the main course and again we're blown away by the bold use of spices and flavors. Our favorite has to be the goat neck biryani which was spicy and decadent, came with a side of raita. Expect walking out feeling spicy and smelling spicy for at least a day or two. In the most marvelous way.
The food was SO good. Highly recommend their papri chaat, bharela marcha, ajwaini paneer tikka and paneer methi
No comment

No comment

I have been waiting to dine here and finally got the reservation. They are reservation only and those are pretty hard to get. I was there with a friend who is vegetarian so we ordered a mix of meat and non meat options. They have quite a few creative cocktails on their menu which is what we kicked off with. Our server David took his time to explain the menu and recommended few things based on our preferences. We ordered papdi chaat, bharela marcha, tabak maaz (lamb ribs), paneer methi and champaran meat (goat). Lamb ribs were melt in the mouth and were sprinkled with a seasoning that added the kick. Paneer Methi was just like how you would cook it a home, with the paneer being fresh (they make their fresh paneer in house  every day). Star of the meal for me was Champaran meat which is spicy and flavorful mutton cooked in a garlicky gravy. The overall meal was amazing and a great experience.
No comment
No comment
No comment

I waited a month to finally get to come here! The cocktails were great, however the food itself was very spicy. Usually there are menu notes that differentiate the very hot menu items from the more subdued menu items from a flavor perspective. The bites of everything I was able to have before my mouth started burning were great. Just wish I could have enjoyed everything! Also the roti is very thin and small.
No comment
No comment

Dining at Dhamaka felt a bit like home with the steel thalis and how they served our food, hot in the pots in which they were cooked. The presentation was creative and the food was delicious. For appetizers, we had the eggplant and paneer. The paneer was probably my favorite dish. For two people, we had more than enough food with two appetizers and the cauliflower as an entree. The cocktails were unique and worth trying. Menus are able to be scanned with a QR code. This was my first indoor dining experience in over a year and definitely worth it (also felt safe). We will be back.
No comment
No comment

As others have mentioned the outside is NOT heated. Do not sit out in the "covered outside" during cold weather, it is not comfortable. When one was able to concentrate on the food and not shivering, it was fine. But overall extremely disappointing.

The authentic menu and spice levels are exactly why I was looking for.  Dishes, spices and flavors were something that I don't always find.  Only down side was the bill for two people... kinda expensive.
It was ok.  It was expensive.  It's one time thing.  I have had better Indian food if not better.  It was just nice to see friends. But the one dessert they have was good.  They just have one.
No comment

After being longtime followers of Rahi and Adda, we couldn't be happier to find this place in time for Valentine's Day. Not pictured were gobi keema and murgh seekh, which were too tasty and fresh to pause for photos. The pao melts in your mouth with the gobi. Best way to describe food: high attention to detail and freshness, yet tastes home-cooked, authentic, and packed with flavor. All cocktails we tried were solid and each very unique, tasty in its own way. Our favorite was the cocktail with melon flavor and also the coconut water. I had some hesitation about placing such high hopes on a place called "Dhamaka," Hindi for 'bang,' but I'm more than happy to report that this place lives up to its name.
No comment
No comment
No comment

We made reservations here a month in advance. First the good, the place definitely has flair with the interior decor, the name itself (Dhamaka means explosion), blasting bollywood tunes, and the creative cocktail list. The grilled paneer arrived first and was our favorite. Beautifully soft and charred and spiced just right. Service was good. Now the not so great. The Eggplant fritters were tender on the inside but lacked flavor. Dishes had a healthy dusting of chaat masala which is great on chaat but not on everything. The fried pompfret looked appetizing with a crunchy coating but the fish inside was insipid and hadnt soaked any of the marinade. The lamb shank was in a beautiful rogan josh-esque red curry, succulent, and very tender, apparently slow cooked for 2 days. But alas it was so spicy that we could not really enjoy it. The veggie pulao was also inedibly spicy. Upon telling the waiter we couldnt eat the food because it was so spicy, he grinned and pointed to his tshirt (that all of the wait staff wear) that says "Unapologetically Indian." The waiter did bring us some free shots of mango lassi which was nice. Finally there was only 1 choice for dessert, a cottage cheese souffle. This place is obviously not kid friendly. Based on the positive reviews of this place, a lot of folks enjoy Dhamaka because they like the adventure and machismo of eating spicy food. However if you are looking for some Indian comfort food with a modern take, this is not it.

Enjoyed the variety of food on Dhamaka's menu and it definitely stands out from your traditional Indian spot. We were seated outside (in the covered tent portion) on a rainy day and did have to desk with some rain leaking through the roof onto our table. My group also felt a tad rushed by service to get seated and get through our meal (hence the 4 not 5 stars). My gulabo drink was definitely my favorite part of my Dhamaka experience.
No comment
No comment
Food was terrible, I would not recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for authentic Indian cuisine.  They're trying way to hard to be different, but the flavors just don't work well together.

Think twice about coming here. It's noisy, and while the wait staff seems helpful, they did nothing about coursing out our dinner. Almost everything arrived at the same time crowding our table while getting cold. The waiter also encouraged us to order more, saying that we didn't order enough based on portion size. But it turned out that we were pressed to over-order. It's at least unwanted 'suation', if not a light form of fraud. As for the food, some was ok, but for the most part it seemed the kitchen used the same spice mix on everything. Boring! Dhamaka is clearly overrated and is probably making use of influencers to create a sense of perfection -- a clear overstatement of reality.
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

Absolutely excellent food at Dhamaka. We started out with the Gurda Kapoora for appetizer. Although it sounded a bit intimidating, definitely a must-try and make sure to dip the bread in the savory broth. For entree, we went with the Goat Neck Dum Biryani and the Lamb Shank Nihari. 5/5 for both the entrees. The portions are huge and the flavor is explosive. A bit spicy, but easy to fight through it with the deliciousness of the meal.

Amazing food and service! As an Indian, the only thing I had a MINOR issue with was the fact that for a table of 6 they'd give us a palm sized portion of Raita(NOONE pays extra for Raita back home)- but you'd have to pay an additional amount to get more Raita. Only relevant for individuals who have a low spice tolerance, so its not a big deal. But all in all, LOVE IT!!
We really had high expectations given the hype. So disappointed. Maybe cause we won't end of the night?
No comment
No comment
No comment

Once you walk near this restaurant you smell that mouth watering aroma of Indian cuisine. Definitely recommend making reservations especially for a weekend. I came here on a friday around 6pm and luckily snagged an outdoor dining table because indoor was fully booked. They do have bar seating too but only drinks and appetizers served there. Luckily the outdoor dining area has a fan so it wasn't too hot even though it was 90 degrees. For drinks we got the kharboozy drink and the passion mango lassi. Both super good. If you like a subtle taste of alcohol but refreshing, kharboozy is the drink for you. The passion mango lassi was mango-y and yummyyy. My bf got two of them! For food we got the ajwani paneer tikka which is kind of like a baked cheese with some onions on the side and a dipping sauce. The highlight of the meal though was the gurda kapoora aka goat testicles. SO. DELICIOUS. Spicy yes but the bread that it comes with goes so well. Light and crunchy bread with bits of goat testicle and kidney. And for main entree we got the goat neck biryani. It was $39 but it was a pretty big portion with a crispy bread coating on the top which they crack and you can dip into a yogurt pomegranate sauce. Overall I really enjoyed my meal and will definitely be back!

This meal was a revelation. We loved the unique menu, and the flavors of each dish we ordered really blew us away. We had the Paplet Fry as our appetizer. For our main courses, we had the Goat Neck Dum Biryani and the Champaran. The Champaran was so tender and rich. The biryani was perfectly spiced and extraordinarily flavorful. Even our leftovers were excellent the next day. We can't wait to come back and try the rest of the menu!

Not sure why there is such a long wait to get a reservation at this place when the food is average overall. The only saving grace is the paneer entry. It was delicious. The rest of the entrees are either way too spicy hot or just plain average. Service was good. Friendly staff. Not sure if I will return though. Overhyped and disappointing.
No comment

I am not Indian and have never been there, so I obviously don't know what I'm talking about, and am only judging the food based on whether it tastes good to me. That said, I thought the dishes were pretty much hit or miss. We started with the chaat and the fried pomfret which were both fantastic. But the prawns and the paneer methi were not as interesting as I expected. There was also a cocktail made with canned chickpea liquid and I say stay away from that one...
No comment
Tasty food but an absolute struggle during a heatwave. Really hoping they start selling the shirts that say "unapologetically indian"

Very good - but the waiter upsold us. He basically told us to double our order and it was way way too much food. I don't know why restaurants tell their employees to do this, it ruins the experience and makes you feel taken advantage of.

I had high hopes for this place but it didn't live up to it. The paneer tikka was bland. The gurda kapoora was too salty and we could only taste spice and salt in the biryani (though the waiter said it was a sixteen layered biryani). Drinks were ok and the service was good.
No comment
No comment
No comment

Paneer tikka was good but other food was quite spicy. There are not too many main course options for vegetarians. We ordered paapdi chat, Mirch bharwan,  paneer tikka, paneer methi and paratha. We had chenna Poda for dessert but were not big fans.
No comment
No comment
Exceptional Indian food. One of the very few restaurants in USA to bring true, deep and soulful Indian flavors. Love it!!

Overhyped and overpriced. Cocktails were tasty and interesting as were appetizers (papdi chaat and paneer tikka were particularly good), but the entrees were spicy-hot for no good reason (who makes a korma so hot that it can't be cut by the cashew cream?) and lacking in interest or creativity. Adda Canteen is more creative, cheaper, and a better bet. Oh, I'm Indian and was not fazed by the spiciness. Just not impressed.
No comment

Overall a decent Indian Restaurant with excellent service and delicious appetizers. Other than the goat neck biryani, all other main dishes had an overwhelming amount of spices that kind of took over any taste of the main ingredients. $200 Rabbit dish was cooked very well but once again all we could taste is just tons of spices. I would highly suggest trying all the appetizers and getting just a biryani for your main and end it with a desert.

Two Lasooni Prawns (garlic prawns in Hindi)  were mouthwatering. On the menu, the ingredients listed were garlic and black pepper. When the chef came to talk to me, I inquired what other spices were in this dish. Yogurt was his answer. "And?" "And if I told you what else you would take my job!" Laughter ensued. Chef Chintan Pandya has won accolades for his adventurous Indian cuisine. Two years ago I ate at Adda Student Canteen in Long Island City. Then a delivery from Rahi so was excited to be here. Located at Essex Market, Dhamaka with its bright red and yellow exterior stands out among the more drab colors of Delancey Street. There is an outdoor covered patio with tables and chairs and the interior which one can access through the entrance of the market. Indian music emanates from the restaurant and it feels lively to be here. Dhamaka offers provincial Indian cuisine which is unusual from the usual offerings of chicken tikka masala at other Indian restaurants. Goat kidneys and testicles? How about Goat Belly? There are also more familiar dishes like Ajwani Paneer and Murgh Kofta for the faint of heart. On my visit, I ate Paplet Fry which is a fish similar to Pomfret in Mumbai and then I ate the two tiger prawns. Raita (yogurt) came with pomegranate seeds that created a colorful tableau. Two paos (rolls) glistened on the plate and just looking at it I felt instantly transported to India where it is ubiquitous, And the flavor? Heavenly and authentic. The severs couldn't get over my adulation of these ordinary rolls. Chef Pandya told me that they make the rolls in house as it was difficult to have other bakeries recreate it. By now I was stuffed but wanted to have the mango lassi. The server was kind to give me a sample in a tiny copper mug. Passion fruit and rosewater transformed the ordinary mango lassi into a spectacular concoction and if it had rum in it I would have been dancing on the tabletops with joy!
No comment

Everything was delicious but the Champaran meat (mutton) definitely stole the show! It comes with a whole head of roasted garlic, which the server mixed with the meat upon serving. Highly recommend but if you are unable to tolerate spice or heat this may not be the place for you. The server I had was very knowledgeable and gave great suggestions based on our tastes, so if you're stumped be sure to ask questions! If I came here again, I'd skip the Doh Khleh. It tasted like pork belly in a cilantro salad. Not bad, and to be honest if I ordered this at any other restaurant it would probably be a star item. But here there are too many other delicious competing dishes on the menu! The Beguni had a really interesting flavor and came within a mustard dip. The Bharela Marcha should not be missed; such an interesting and delicious flavor combination: spicy, sweet and peanut-y.
Worth making a trip back to NYC just for their Champaran meat!!! Incredible food and drinks!

No comment

I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed the food here. While they only have a few vegetarian dishes on the menu, it is absolutely vegetarian friendly! We got the ragda pattice, pulao, and both paneers - all so different in flavor but right on point! Drinks were also great and hit the spot.
No comment
It not Indian fusion but really good food! Busy and buzzing casual place to hang out with friends. Definitely try appetizers. Drinks were okay.

column3: Old Fourth Ward, Ann Arbor, MI
column6: This place is very good and it takes boujee Indian food to another level. The drinks are very unique and taste good as well. The lamb ribs and baby chicken were so tender. They both were marinated well. The fried fish appetizer was only seasoned on one side.
No comment
Outstanding. The best biryani I've ever had. Dhamaka is already a favorite and we can't wait to come back!
Absolutely AMAZING. Would recommend every single dish on the menu. Personal favourite - The Mutton biryani.
