No comment
Sadly did not live up to the hype. I'll yield that the panner tikka was delicious, but the rest of our choices were mediocre (Champaran Meat, Chicken Pulao, Ragda Pattice).
No comment
No comment

Amazing food and service! I am familiar with many of the items being from Bangladesh but they were able to add their own touch and enhance some very authentic Bengali dishes. My favorite are the lamb ribs and Goat neck biryani. Amazing blend of flavors. This is the place to go if you want to have a delicious meal that you will always remember!

We managed to snag walk-in seats at the bar and were thrilled with every part of our meal. Service is spectacular and friendly, from the hostess to the bartenders. The Sadak Chhap is a very interesting drink that we loved at first, but make sure to drink it quickly before the flavors separate. They have tons of GF options, which was a lovely surprise. The Ragda Pattice is tasty, although too much cilantro for this cilantro tastes like soap gal. Beguni was melt in uh our mouth, although I didn't like the mustard sauce that came with it. The Paplet Fry was my favorite once we learned how to eat it. Be warned, there are a ton of bones, but it's still worth it! And my husband devoured the Gurda Kapoora. I tried a bite and the flavors were incredible. And you should definitely get the made-to-order Chena Poda. We can't wait to make a res and experience the full menu. What an incredible addition!

Don't get what all the hype is all about. There are many other expensive Indian restaurants in the city if you want a different experience with Indian food. We were 50/50 on liking and really disliking what we ordered. Paneer tikka was by far the best. We couldn't eat the lamb chops or eggplant because the lamb was really fatty and gamely. The eggplant was mostly the deep fried breading, which wasn't clear from the menu that it would be prepared like that. The potato patties were also confusing - pretty much it was mashed potatoes with Chana dal and various other chaat fixings. The chicken kofta curry was good and I'd get it again along with the paneer. The food isn't as spicy as its reputation but some dishes are coated in red chili so have similar tastes (lamb chops and eggplant.)

Stopped in heat for dinner and was very happy with the quality of the food. Amazing flavors and plenty of food. The service was great and the owner stopped by to talk with us. You can tell he has passion for the food and his customers.
No comment

Of all the restaurants I've been to, Dhamaka is easily the one I get asked about the most. That's why, even though it's been 4 months since I visited, I feel I would be remiss not to feature it on this nascent account. The energy of Dhamaka is reminiscent of the college buddy we all had for whom a few sips of alcohol unlocked a fount of adoration for everyone around him. In saying that, I do not mean to suggest that Dhamaka is drunken and unfocused. It's emphatically not. The restauranteur behind the project, Roni Mazumdar, came to our table (likely alerted to our presence by the rapidity of our gurda kapoora, macher jhol, and champaran consumption) and told us about the multi-year research process that went into the restaurant's beautiful and bawdy Indian village food. But in Roni's attentiveness (and, of course, Chef Chintan Pandya's reverent cooking), you can get a sense of the mix of enthusiasm and joy and earnestness and empathy that Dhamaka channels into their singular menu and colorful space, and that I meant to evoke with my analogy. These are unabashed, assertively-spicy curries. The basis of each is a caramelized paste of ginger-forward, salty aromatics laden with green chiles that you find yourself scraping from the bottom of the vessel long after you've consumed all of the dish's featured protein. If you are looking for creamy tikka masala and its ilk, go elsewhere. At Dhamaka, the richness comes from an ample layer of chili-inflected oil that slicks eat bite as you lift it from the pan to your lips. Eating here is transportive. It's escapism at its most grounded and intentional. We may soon find our lives impinged again by Delta, but at least we will still have Dhamaka.

Had a heard a lot about this place so went in today since I was visiting NYC. I ordered the chamaparan meat since I was told by my server that this would be less spicy one in menu. The dish was good. Would rate an 8/10. The sweet dish however was the star.
Authentic and delicious Indian restaurant. You can feel the love that went into this place. Food, service and decor. Fantastic.
SPICY!!!! This is coming from someone who loves spicy food but when spicy is the only flavor you taste then the food becomes less enjoyable. The fried fish and chaat was my favorite.

Tasty place ! They have t-shirts that say "Unapologetic Indian" on it so if you like strongly flavored authentic food you will like Dhamaka on Delancey street. Definitely get the eggplant Beguni appetizer. Wow ! That was so surprising with hot mustard ! Really good. My friend got grilled lamb ribs and liked that . The prawn grill only came with one and although it was tasty I'd try the peanut and pepper grill next time. The paneer methi main course is big ! And delicious. Recommended. I took some home with me. Rice doesn't come with the mains so order some on the side. My friend got the baby shark and this was also surprisingly good, different and had a lot of meat in it. As far as bread , I thought the Chapati was better than the paratha but I wish the Chapati was bigger ( wish they had naan actually! ) The drinks aren't too big but they were also flavorful and unique. My friend got two of the NRI which is a tasty coconut milk and scotch and Cointreau drink, tasty. I got the betel leaf and gin and ginger liqueur Paan e Bahar drink and that was nice and definitely different. I also got the mezcal and passion fruit Joshila drink and even for someone who doesn't like mezcal it was good because the fruit cuts a lot of the smokiness. They only had one dessert available so we skip that one and went inside the Essex Market instead. Downstairs in the Essex Market is Ample Hills ice cream which I think is open til 9pm.Get the Oatmeal lace flavor,that was like a snicker doodle cookie, nice

It took us a couple of weeks to get a table but the food was absolutely worth it. Hands down this place has the best Indian food in New York. Eating at Dhamaka felt like eating in New Delhi. Highly recommended!

After hearing all the rave reviews, we were so excited to come here on a Friday night. Dhamaka did not disappoint! The food is spiced to perfection, though I wouldn't call it authentic by any means. We were a bit skeptical on their dessert, but the other dishes and drinks were phenomenal. Tucked away in Essex market, the vibe feels very young and millennial.
No comment

#bestindianfood in NYC, Tenzy was amazing and his recommendations were fantastic..  the paneer melts in your mouth , reminds you of " ghar ka khana" homemade food .. please please give this place a Michelin star  it truly deserves one

What a pleasant experience! The servers were very friendly and knowledgeable of their menu. We tried multiple appetizers and shared a main among the two of us and ended up ordering too much food. We typically don't eat spicy food so it was definitely on the spicier side but we loved experiencing these new flavours. The cocktails were outstanding as well. The service was a tad rushed but they made sure that our anniversary was an unforgettable experience! Highly recommend Dhamaka!
No comment
Vegetarians dream catcher. Try Pulao. Marcha. Oh and Bharela. Thanks chef Chintan Pandya!

This place was on every nyc 2021 must go to restaurant list and it definitely met expectations! The drinks were amazing especially the NRI and paan-e-bahar.  The paan drink actually tasted like paan and was so unique . As for the food my favorites were: the lamb chops (tabak maaz) ( so tender fall off the bone), the pressure cooker chicken puloa (I could swim in it), and surprisingly the parathas ( soft and buttery ). Unfortunately the dessert was sold out so order it at the beginning to make sure . I would 100% recommend this place .  We also had the biryani, the champaran, the panneer methi, the lasooni prawn and the special trout . Nothing was a miss. Also the service was impeccable ! Our server was Eddie and he really made our experience 5 star as  did the host/chef who was graciously attending to each table .
No comment

We recently dined at Baar Baar, another restaurant that describes itself as upscale Indian food. The food here at Dhamaka was head and shoulders more flavorful than Baar Baar. Both places were a little pricey, but I would say Dhamaka was worth it. We had 3 small plates and the vegetable pulau, along with 2 servings of bread, which was just enough, I think. The gin and betel leaf cocktail was really tasty, as well. We'll definitely be going back.

I visited the place yesterday. I found the place and hostess nice and polite. But, food quality failed to impress me. This is not above average food served in many Indian restaurant in NY and adjoining places in NJ etc. I certainly didn't find the food comparable to other know Indian restaurants like Tamarind, Indian accent or others. I added these other names because the cost of this place was almost equal to these well know places, but food failed to elevate to the expected level. I might not visit the place again. For me it was one time visit.
No comment

The food here was great-- we tried the paplet fry, papri chaat, the goat seekh kebabs, and achari paneer, and I would definitely come back to try some of the other highly rated items -- the goat neck biryani looked amazing! That said, for all the hype, there were other parts of our experience that were quite disappointing. Our cocktails were very watered down, and lacked taste-- yet were priced at $17-$18. And service was really off-- our waiter couldn't really answer our questions about the menu, forgot a drink order, and at the end of the meal, asked us kind of rudely why we only ordered appetizers (even though we ordered 4 appetizers between two people, which ended up costing as much as two entrees!) We've been frequent clients at Rahi and Adda and have loved our experiences there, so hopefully these little issues smooth out with time.

The deeper dive into the cuisine of the subcontinent is what Dhamaka is doing. It's the thesis statement. Regional favorites done the right way. If you're expecting chicken tikka or malai kebab or chana masala or butter chicken... this is not the place. You will not find any of the typical Indian restaurant menu names on this menu. Not only is it regional but it's typical dabha / street food aggressive too. This is why you're seeing a lot of people saying its over spiced or too spicy. For some, the flavors come out of left field if you're too used to Punjabi Indian food, but for others, it's the level of Indian cuisine you simply cannot find at other indian restaurants. Be ready to treat each dish as it's own individual oasis. This isn't a put it all together, add some rice and eat it type place. This place requires your attention and determination. The raw spices are used to the fullest and rawest extent. The heat is coming more from the raw spices that actual extra chili powder on most dishes. The seekh kebab is divine. The biryani is almost as perfect as you could ask for from a restaurant. It's all good. It's all worth trying. This is a super fun and cool Environment as well to try this angle and take on Indian food as well. The cocktails are mos definitely unique and a must try. One of the most crucial things that Dhamaka does perfectly is the onion and chutney that comes with some of the dishes. The onion and chutney is the key part of Indian meals for a lot of people. You will not be disappointed by the onion and chutney! Also, the prawns. You've never tried prawns like this. I will bet you any amount of money. Next time I come here, I'm only ordering those prawns!  Wow! Amazing work team Dhamaka! Bravo!
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

Really good.  Lamb ribs, paneer eggplant fritters, papalet were all good .  The chicken pualu was spicy and tasty, but the chicken itself was mediocre.  The paneer in cashew cream was hearty and a solid order.  Definitely worth the hype

Extremely nice staff and extremely overhyped. It was good but just not amazing or special. We got the recommended Champaran Meat and Goat Neck Dum Biryani. I've had better biryani. The Champaran was good but just not amazing. Also they seem to have basically no heat lamps in their outdoor dining which is very weird and makes it very cold.
Best Indian food in the city. The lamb is spiced to perfection and the mutton is an explosion of garlicky goodness. The mixed drinks can be slightly odd but some hit the spot.

Food was excellent. Service was efficient. Flavors are authentic and well spiced. The goat biryani and the chicken from the tandoori grill were the standouts for me. I would come back and try more dishes.

Just happened to drop in for cocktails. We had to order food per prevailing virus rules. Not your usual Indian food. Delicious! Cocktails really good, too. Service very attentive and informative. Can't wait to return for a full meal. This restaurant is a gem.
No comment

The food was nice but i found it to be really overpriced. We sat outside and it was kind of cold, sadly they only had two heaters which couldn't reach our table. Overall the food is good but not good enough to justify the prices. The ambiance is whatever, still kind of in Essex market.
No comment
Food is good/ drink are ok if I be  generous. They certainly need to work on the service.though
The ambiance, food, and the service was amazing.  Much kudos to the chef and the team   food presentation and taste was tremendous!!

Loved my meal! Everything was incredibly tasteful, bursting of spices. I loved the spice level. Warning: I do have a high spice threshold. My husband, who cannot handle spicy food as well as I can, was a bit in pain. But he said he would definitely go back because the food was that good.

Came with high expectations, left very disappointed. Ordered the Joshila cocktail - which was delicious, well made. Ordered the Doh Khleh for starters and it was decent. The Paneer Methi was so full of cream that I could couldn't taste the Methi or the spices. Goat Neck Biryani was another disappointment. It was dry and the flavor has not quite blended with the rice, difficult to describe but I'm a huge Biryani fan and this was the worst I've even had.

We ordered the papdi chaat and ragda pattice to start. Both were incredibly flavorful, and according to my GF, who is from Delhi, also really authentic. Next we had the champaran mutton curry and the dhamaka dal, with the ghee rice. Again, both were great. We also ordered the jumbo prawns, which was the standout dish, in my opinion - some of the best I've ever had. The staff was incredibly accommodating and thoughtful. Though they did take temperatures when we first walked in, they noticed that we were particular about social distancing, and immediately moved our table a full 15 feet away from others. Our server Georgie was also really sweet and helpful. Will definitely be returning.
Excellent food. Not one of those crappy orange curry with so called naan. This is real Indian food
No comment

Not just a burst of spice, but spice on steroids. That's how I would describe my experience at Dhamaka.  I will never forget my meal there, as it was more like an emotional experience -- very powerful!  I started with the Kharboozy at the bar -- a potent mix of Aperol, fresh cantaloupe, and lime.  The bartender promised me that there was no extra sugar and that the taste specifically came from the natural flavors of the cantaloupe.  At the table, I started with the Kagda Pattice.  More like a main meal, it included a potato patty buried in a tasty white pea and green chili sauce.  Then came my main dish, the Murgh Kofta.  When the server opened the pot, I was completely surprised by a ball of chicken mintz which included an egg (they told me) and was dredged in an extremely spicy sauce which included poppy seeds.  Relief from the spices came from the Gulaabo, a gin drink concoction with dragon fruit, rose water, and lemon -- exquisite. Next time I am in for the Chicken Masala Pulso made of bone-in chicken, cinnamon, and basmati rice.  The service was excellent.  The place itself is in a small area inside the Essex Market.  If you are waiting for a table, you can check out the market and drink citrus hops beer in the basement (just what I did!)
Their food and their service are both really excellent- I will be happy to go back anytime for their delicious food! Thank you to the staff for your excellent work!

Quite disappointed. Lassi was too sweet, pulav was like red chili rice, Raita was just yogurt with pomegranates, paneer was fresh but had no flavor. Saving grace was ragda patties, but rest were all not good. Nothing "unapologetically Indian" about it

Another new entry at the Essex Market, which is initially created to support small businesses with fresh, affordable but quality goods. However, after the move and renovation, it's hard to deny that services and products charge mid range prices, but still good to know all businesses are locally owned and not blockbuster chains. Dhamaka comes with great accolades, with chef Chintan Pandya and restaurateur Roni Mazumdar, the dream team behind of Adda and Rahi. The menu would be different from the ubiquitous Indian joint, this restaurant will break the chain and introduce a range of dishes that represent foods from many different parts of the Mother land. Be adventurous and find doh khleh, a pork salad from the northeastern Indian state of Meghalaya or paplet fry, which is fried pomfret dish from the western Indian state of Maharashtra.  Eating through the menu is like travelling across India, without the flights.  The decor is colorful and festive,  like the casual sibling of Rahi, and a common cousin of Adda. There is no better time to embrace diversity and debunk stigma and bias than eating unapologetic foods.
No comment

We went for dinner with friends. The table was reserved and waiting for us. The ambiance was cool and with great Bollywood music. The service was excellent. We ordered a number of starters and 3 mains. The papri chaat, the beguni and the curry with bread were delicious. The fried pomfret, the biryani, the gurda and methi paneer were outstanding. I thought the chicken kofta was good but should have been served with at least two koftas for the amount of curry. The biryani was good too. The cocktails were a bit expensive but well done. Overall, an excellent Authentic Indian food experience.
This place doesn't get more authentic real Indian food. The paplet , goat biryani and champaran meat were absolute highlights! Would definitely come back !
The food was absolutely amazing. It was pretty nice to try Indian food from different regions.

Cool spot / fun vibe, but unfortunately the food fell very flat. We were excited to try a lot of different things on the menu, and only the paplet fry and lamb ribs were good. The rest of the dishes ranged from mediocre to completely unappealing. Sad outcome as we had high hopes.

We had such a wonderful meal at Dhamaka!! Everything was so incredibly delicious, cannot wait to come back and try more dishes. The hostess, server and owner were all also extremely hospitable, which is very much appreciated.

Incredible food, service, and energy. Everything we ordered was incredible and really appreciated the support and preparation for allergies.
Good vibes, great food as simple as that! Staff was very kind and helpful. Will be back again.

First time trying aguachiles- was blown away by the negro campechanos aguachiles. The habanero has a slow burn but it's the perfect level of heat. Also tried the Amarillo one which was also tasty, but has less of a kick. Loved the tostada de viera (raw scallops). The fish tacos had the perfect crisp. This restaurant should be on every foodie's must eat list!! The restaurant is a seafood focused Mexican restaurant and if you've been a fan of Contramar in Mexico City, you will love Ensenada! The super highlight of the night for me was the perfectly cooked butterflied roasted fish that came with fresh hot tortillas. Can't wait to be back for another fun mezcal and seafood night.

As Mexican Americans, my wife and I can say this is the best authentic Mexican seafood we've had in the five boroughs. The tuna tostadas and Al pastor fish are amazing and our go to. We've added this place to our list of favorites in the city. We'll continue to be back.
A new favorite with incredibly fresh seafood, awesome drinks and great vibe. Amazing tacos and the patatas bravas are an underrated star. Love this spot

Absolutely spectacular! Our party of 3 got the scallop Tostadas, aguachile sampler, Branzino al pastor tacos and the hibiscus dessert. The Branzino al pastor were not just one of the best tacos I've had in NYC, but in my life (and I lived in Los Angeles for 6 years). That dish reminded me of Cosme's incredible kampachi al pastor, especially with the pineapple butter. My jaw essentially hit the floor after the first bite of the dessert, so complex and otherworldly. The service and drinks were major highlights too. Overall, would say Ensenada is one of Brooklyn's best-kept secrets and the trek from Manhattan is 1000% worth it.

Went here last night. Food was incredible - salsa flight, chips and guac were amazing. The guac was too onion-forward for my friend (who is a chef btw for what it's worth) but no complaints from me! Tuna tostada appetizer was next. Chef friend had doubts before it came. She thought it was going to be one of those teensy tiny one-bites that you pop in your mouth. No chef! The tuna tostada app is full of flavor with a surprise of toasted sesame and each is the size of your palm - many bites. Next up was the aguachiles - which is a form of ceviche (raw fish in broth?). I had the verde version - bright green, fragrant, herbal, spicy. Chef had the negro - deep brown, lots of heat, rich, spicy. We had smoky mescal and a couple cocktails, too. All of it delicious! Good service too. I'd definitely go again.

Food was amazing- the flavor packed in every bite was incredible. Service was also great and very nice staff. We ordered the guacamole, tuna tostadas, shrimp ceviche, fish tacos and patatas bravas. Already planning my next visit when I can do the whole order all over again!

The food and drinks here at so awesome - and so good that I came to eat here two nights in a row. This is fish-forward, authentic, super fresh Mexican food the quality of which I would compare to Atla. Everything I've had so far has been delicious, and I can't wait to keep coming back for more aguachiles!

The menu is uninspiring and overpriced ($17 for 2 tacos, $15 for guacamole, $13 for chips & salsa), and I couldn't find anything I wanted to eat. I decided to leave, but the server was very pushy about ordering something, although I can't blame her because the place was completely empty on a Saturday night.

Very pricey for omurice, but it's the best I've had in NYC so far! The rice wasn't too salty and was fried and mixed with sausage. The eggs were just the right texture and mixed really well with the flavorful curry. The environment was comfortable too, so I would visit @aoikitchenny again!

We went to Aoi Kitchen on Sunday afternoon for a late lunch. We probably waited for 5 mins to get seated. They have a nice waiting area with a comfortable couch. Overall restaurant is really nice and calming environment. We ordered omurice and loco moco. Food was delicious and side dishes that came with were also very delicious. Portion wise it's a bit small for the price. I am giving Aoi Kitchen 4 stars instead of 5 is because it is a big pricey for what it is. I would definitely come back for their delicious food though!!

Aoi Kitchen is the bomb! So impressed with the decor, the venue, the service, and especially the food. This place offers Japanese mini set meals, essentially a main entree and several sides and soup. The katsu and omurice was delicious, but the hamburg steak is probably the best. Love this place.
No comment

for once the camera did not eat first. was so hungry and the food was so good that i totally forgot. the mentaiko pasta is so so good and i will be dreaming about it for a long time. the staff was also so friendly and nice. i ordered green tea (i love tea) and never saw the bottom of the cup and will definitely be coming back to this place
Really cool decor. Food is the perfect japanese comfort food. Best omurice and loco moco I've ever had
Food is okay. I like the Japanese style cell set especially during the pandemic. The waiter is really awesome.

We (teenager included) were quite pleased at how simple and beautiful each dinner order was.  Not only was each set tastefully put together with side salad, kimchi, miso soup, yellowtail, and jello, it wasn't greasy or sloppy - simply perfect for a party of four.  Seating at a floor table with floral decor over our heads made our family outing a wonderful moment shared.  We left very satisfied and happy.

We ordered delivery from here with Caviar. Tonkatsu box and the loco moco.  Both were delicious and extremely well packaged.   Delivery was fast and the items received in great shape.  We will definitely repeat.
No comment
I love the KARAAGE. It's the best karaage ive ever had!!!!!! A little expensive. Spent 110$ for 2 people today. Nice vibe and nice hosts

Delicious Japanese comfort food with cozy ambiance. We got two set meals (teishoku), one with omurice and the other with the AOI (ham) katsu. Both were super tasty and you definitely can't go wrong with the omurice -- what started out as an impossibly large mound of egg stuffed goodness was completely devoured, down to the last grain of rice. The katsu had a nice shattery crust that didn't feel heavy at all, and the ham was delicately flavored (not too salty). We wanted to try the loco moco but they didn't have it the night we went. We will be back next time to check it out.
Heard great thing about this place. I think the food is quite good, just not extremely amazing.  The portion is right and customer survives is nice. It is a nice spot for Japanese comfort food
No comment
Take the steps down into Aoi Kitchen for a cozy cafe study atmosphere featuring an affordable set-dining experience. Try the crispy Aoi Katsu and decadent Omurice!

Thier omurice is a top-notch Japanese styled in nyc!   my othrr favorites are ebi sando, cream crab croquettes, and the tamagoyaki! Besides! Mostly their indoor vibe can't be ignored!!! Awesome vibes & music

Walking down the stairs into their super comfy set up was nice and exciting. Not many tables but it is perfect for small intimate dinner or lunch setting. You can not go wrong, order anything you like and the meal will be cooked amazing. Everything is fresh and local produce. The server was super nice and helpful. Very clean and inviting inside. Can't wait to come back!
No comment

came here w some friends & we all loved it! everything was so good and really affordable price for the amount you get. the portions were a good size! if you're into japanese food, you should def try this place out. it also has a nice ambiance and prdecor
The food doesn't worth the hype and it's pretty expensive where I can get better food that are cheaper around Astor place.
It was just ok. Food was mediocre. It might have tasted better if the food were hot. All three of our dishes were barely warm.

Came here twice to try this place out and was rejected twice. First time - they were randomly not open one day. No note on why or anything. Then the next time I arrived at 3:15 when they close at 4. And they rejected seating me when there was a good 45 minutes. And from a tip I saw on yelp, the kitchen closes at 3:30. I had more than ample time to order and eat. Do yourselves a favor and list a last seating time instead of closing time - because no one can guess. And after driving a 2 hour commute and arriving with ample time - this type of service is uncalled for.

Really really chill ambience. They serve lemon water which I loved. I ordered the omurice and I went with my sister who got the katsu sando. I was definitely full and satisfied from the omurice which thank god was not just plain white rice. They also had some meat in there so it really made the difference. I also took a bite of the spicy mayo katsu sando (theres two halves of the katsu sando with different stuff on it)... I wish my sister saved me some of the other one but I want to say that it can definitely be better. The quality and the amount of meat and fat of the katsu was not to my liking.

Got the mentaiko pasta which tasted fine but the food took so long to come out and once I was done, I felt very sick. Definitely something wrong with the food because I feel really awful even now. Very disappointed and a waste of money.

Super comfy lunch spot that you must go to! The lighting made everything look vintage and makes you really relax from paper headaches. I love the sauce from the omurice, flavorful and soft eggs. My friend had a ham Katsu which is super crispy! The side dishes are a super plus, small yet delightful. And the decorations are just amazing, the ceiling is a must for insta!

The food is so good and the service is exceptional. Already planning my next visit! I had the AOI Katsu, which was very flaky and tender. Plus the green tea dessert was yum. The ambiance is low key and stylish. One note: they didn't appear to serve any alcohol.
Divine. So good. Get their omurice, or loco moco, or mentaiko pasta. you won't regret it.

Beautiful and cute place. There was a bit of a wait when I got there around 7, but there are a bunch of seats to sit in while u wait. I ordered the Loco Moco and I was really good. It comes with a thick seasoned patty topped with a perfectly cooked sunny side egg on top of a bed of white rice which is surrounded by a tomato soup/sauce. It comes with 3 sides, a miso soup, and a dessert. The waiter was super kind and explained everything. I would definitely come to try something else again. I could not stop admiring the ceilings covered in flowers :)
Is it Taimeiken?  No but Aoi's omurice hits the spot, and is quite satisfying.  I wish the demiglace sauce had more wine and beef stock in it.
Delicious - the best Japanese food  Boulder. As a vegetarian, I certainly appreciate the variety of choices!

This is a little restaurant in a basement. It is very cozy place and its food is DELICIOUS. However, it's a little too small and you probably need to arrive earlier to get a seat. I'm telling you the wait is worth it. I highly suggest you try their omurice. The egg is cooked at the perfect state. It's so smooth. The rice is perfectly fried. It comes with some salad and a bowl of miso soup. It worths its price. 5 Stars!!

This place is amazing!!! So much value with your order, two amazing sides, soup, salad, and a cute dessert. The omurice was so silky. The ham katsu was so crispy and good with the sauce! Definitely want this place to stick around so I'm leaving them a great review. The service is so attentive. Love this place.
Food was great, cozy and nice interior, excellent staff, good price. One of the best Japanese restaurants in the city!
Food is DELICIOUS..I really enjoyed the skinless tomato appetizer! The owners were really nice and welcoming. I went there a couple times and trust me, will be there again!!

Walked by couple times and finally got a chance to check out this place! Overall, the food was decent, especially their loco moco. Will probably give 9.6/10. Their homemade brown sauce works really well with the beef patty. The sauce is a little on the sweet end, but can be covered by having a scoop of white rice below. I would suggest a different menu other than the omurice to try out different tastes of Japanese comfort food. Would def come back and try out other menus too!

I was excited to try the place and specifically traveled to the area to go here.  Unfortunately they decided to stop letting people in and said they were closed. I arrived at 3:13 pm and online it says 4pm.  When I asked for clarification about their hours it was super vague.  Very disappointing

Came in and told a server we were waiting for a friend. But he kept pushing us so hard to order before my friend comes in.  So we did and my food came 3mins after the order. My chicken dish and side rice were all cold while sashimi was room temperature. My bf's omurice was cold too. I told them it's too cold. So they remade it and came out hot but the fried chicken was still so soggy. I'm sure they fried the chicken and marinate with the sauce already. just heated it up when I ordered and served. And sashimi was left outside of fridge for a while. My friend's pork katsu is freshly fried but so dry. The only good thing there was katsu sandwich. For $25, I expected freshly fried crispy chicken not cold and soggy one. Gave 2 stars only because they remade my food. Won't recommend at all.

For starters, I think the price is a little too over the top. $23 for a omurice dish is pretty ridiculous. Not to mention the price of other dishes there, too. On top of that, the food, while not terrible, was a little salty. We also ordered a tonkatsu sandwich, which was again not bad (the contents were pretty good) but again Id say it is not worth the listed price and the bread that was used for sandwich was definitely a little too hard. Overall, I do not think it is worth the price.

This place is clean, friendly, and most of all super tasty food! The loco Moto, omurice and sesame latte were all amazing. They also have Orion beer on tap. Just come at odd times otherwise you won't get a seat. This place is hot right now.
awesome place. decor is pretty nice. food is good. omurice is good. prices are a little expensive but worth it

Very good food. Set meals come at a reasonable price. Comfortable and unique interior design: combines the feel of a japanese restaurant with a lounge, with hint of library from a green library lamp at some tables. Relatively spacious too for a nyc restaurant. They don't cram you in. Expect a wait.

My friend and I came here for dinner, which started at 5:30. There are a lot of cute decorations and the atmosphere is very nice. We got the omurice and the curry pork katsu which are both really good. I like how they both came in a set where a couple of side dishes, miso soup, and a small dessert was included. Since it came in a set, the food was very filling and was worth the money. Just be aware that the prices are a couple of dollars higher than the ones shown on yelp.
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

it was ok not good as i expected. the amount of rice was alot but the amount of meat was little. Lucky that i ordered ramen and it so good that i can use the soup to eat with it. Maybe im not a big fan of these. If you in the area why not try see if it fit your taste
No comment

Love the onigiri choices here. It's a great snack to have in a pinch. I tried the spicy tuna, salmon, and spam musabi. You can't go wrong with any of those choices. Nice sticky rice. Good location since it's near Grand Central Station and it's located within a Japanese grocery store that reminded my of the 7-11 locations in Japan.
Very nice and unique selection of fresh onigiri and Masubi. They have brown rice options and have some pretty flavorful offerings.
No comment

I found this little gem while searching for a quick, casual lunch spot near Grand Central. Such a great Japanese convenience store with lots of prepared food options. I only tried the spicy tuna, salmon and chasiu pork onigiri and spam musubi but they were all delicious and filling.  Only complaint was the ratio of rice to filling. A little heavy on the rice but since the rice was cooked perfectly, I didn't mind. I also noticed that they offered ramen with a couple of small tables if you choose to dine in. This place reminded me of the convenience stores in Asia. Wish there were more places like this around the city!
No comment
A bit hard to find, this is on a side street, inside of a grocery store, but a good selection of different musubis that weren't too expensive. Great to take on the go!
Best Japanese rice ball shop in nyc. Prices are super affordable between $2-4 for your most basic veggie base to the bomb with salmon and tuna. Authentic and a great snack or meal.

Was looking for Japanese food in midtown East and was so excited to see that there was an Omusubi Gonbei (they have a location in 'Mitsuwa which my siblings and I all love.) i got a kakiage rice ball and a fried oyster and my mom got a kombu one I think. I also picked up a chasu pork for my SO. The kakiage was   oyster was great too though there was too much mayo for my liking (though, I am also someone who largely dislikes mayo ). There are a ton of options here and they're all still if not warm than at least not cold (unlike the refrigerated onigiri you get at most grocery stores). If you like onigiri and are close by I definitely recommend picking something up!
No comment

Fantastic little Japanese onigiri stand inside Katagiri Japanese market. It's CHEAP!!! You can actually eat a meal for under $5!!! They have Natto (fermented soybean), kombu (seaweed), ume (picked plum), mustard greens, many brown rice and veggie options. They also have tuna, salmon, etc. Some Japanese shops don't get the rice to filling ratio correct. This one is PERFECT!!! Not too much rice, and the rice itself is perfectly seasoned so it's full of flavor. I would come by again for some nice snacks when I'm on the go.
No comment
No comment
No comment

Gosh this place is fantastic. I've been to the one in Mitsuwa Marketplace and Katagiri. The Katagiri location didn't have anyone manning the station but the wide variety of musubis were placed out to grab and take to the register. They have all kinds of flavors from traditional (ume, salmon) to more adventurous (spicy chicken, takana, eel). You can't go wrong with the classics like salmon and spicy tuna but the spicy chicken is really good. They're so fluffy and huge. Two of them would be more than enough for a meal. They are kept warm somehow and are just so satisfying to bite into. They're freshly made and ready to eat. No need to assemble like the ones you get in some markets/convenience stores. If you're looking for something quick and filling don't sleep on this option. Katagiri has lots of good drinks, bento, and sushi to go along with your musubi as well.

Difficult to find the store since the map was directing me to another area. The shop is small but service was quick! Inside seems to be a market selling some Japanese snacks and groceries. I got a variety of different things to try and my favorite was the fried oyster rice ball. The food is better fresh and was filling. Would come again for a quick bite for my train ride :)

Was in the area after brunch at little Collins and wanted something to nibble on my flight back. It is tucked in the front of the japanese market. I wanted the spicy tanaka but they were out, so I opted for the shiso/mackerel which was HUGE. I can make my own making rice ball but this one was good. I was worried that since it was so big that it would be flavorless and dry but nope, it was perfectly seasoned. Would try some other flavors. Like the spam and egg, unagi and spicy tuna next time
No comment

Stopped by here to grab a few musubis and I believe it was a spicy salmon don? All very good and tasty, especially the spicy salmon! I had a flight the same day, wish I could have ate these on the plane home. Great little market in NYC for an out-of-towner! Thank you! :)

.I love the fact they have different favor of rice but maybe i'm greedy, i think it they add little more meat in it would be taste better. It also need little more favor for me. It taste better after i dipped it in ramen. For the price it is not bad for what i pay for. would i try it again. Maybe. Just not my favor.

Only tried the takeaway onigri and all 3 choices were super yummy. I hope to return and try some more. They clearly labeled the veg options too. The shop itself is cute and has lots of Japanese food essentials. Definitely recommend if you want some inexpensive, filling, quick, yummy food.

After spending some time in Hawaii and eating spam musubi every morning, Omusubi Gonbei definitely more than scratches that perpetual spam musubi itch. Not much more needs to be said other than to come here in the morning to grab some freshly made and delicious musubi/onigiri.
No comment
So yum and so fresh!  We got an assortment including the oyster, natto, and mentakio.

Unbelievably skimpy on filings. You're better off buying the rice balls from the supermarket because you'll be paying a dollar less for all that rice. My chair siu rice ball had 3 pieces of meat. 3 pieces that are each less than the size of a dime. Spicy tuna was literally a nickel size worth of tuna. Such a ripoff.
No comment
Super delicious for a great price! I'm vegetarian and got the seaweed onigiri and veg tempura onigiri. It was a great takeaway lunch!

Absolutely love this deli. They offer so much food in such a small space. They have rice balls, ramen, snacks, Mochi, and everything you can imagine. I came here on a cold day for some ramen and honestly it was so delicious. I ordered the #1, the broth was so good and not too salty. The pork belly was so tender and soft at the same time. I love every bit of this ramen . Would definitely come back for their other rice dishes!
No comment

Such a great, easy and very delicious on the go meal. Packed with good carbs, protein and flavor. Such a simple thing to get but so satisfying for such a reasonable price which is one big thing I look for. Not only is it good but they are heftier than they seem so able to fill you up! Definitely will be going back frequently to pick one up every once in awhile!
No comment

OMG, such a hidden gem! The rice balls are huge with generous fillings, made fresh daily by the nicest people, prices are super reasonable. My favorite item to bring on a plane ride since it's pure comfort food!!

The food is pretty good but it takes way too long to get help if you want something quickly to go. Take your money to sunrise mart just 2 blocks down.
No comment

I like you Omusubi Gonbei, I like you a lot. Prime location and service was great. I will have to admit, Pickled Plum was really incredible. I think that I might have a new favorite dish now. The team was extremely friendly and service is outstanding. Omusubi Gonbei...What a great spot.

These are great rice balls, just like you would get from an omusubi counter in Japan. Located inside Katagiri Japanese grocery/convenience store, you order at the Omsubi Gonbei counter and pay at the Katagiri register. I tried a salmon onigiri and a mentaiko onigiri. Both were packed with evenly distributed fillings. The quality of the food was great - the rice was cooked well. While you don't get the crispy seaweed from a pre-wrapped rice ball, you do get a better quality product overall between the rice and the fillings. Definitely worth a stop if you're in the area!
Tasty and fresh onigiris! The rice was soft and had plenty of fillings. Great deal for the quality and taste. Staff is also very friendly - I look forward to coming back!

Really cheap and great lunch deals! Each rice ball is $2-4 tops, and the sides are just as inexpensive. The rice balls are massive compared the the smaller and flatter rice balls from other rice ball chains. I ordered the bomb rice ball (comes with tuna, salmon, and soy marinated kelp). Highly recommend this, great combination of flavors if you want a sampler all in one and can't choose between multiple fillings. The spicy tuna was equally delicious and very filling. Thought it would be mostly rice and very little filling, but there is actually a decent amount of filling inside. You can order from the counter and have them pack it for you or you can head further into the store and check out the deli section where there are more bento boxes, drinks, etc. They also have a prepacked lunch deal in the deli section during weekdays that comes with 2 rice balls and the karaage! Will definitely be stopping by again to try other rice balls.
No comment
So glad I stumbled across these guys. A large array of options, large portions, and really affordable prices for fresh, warm onigiri. I have already recommended it to friends!
No comment
No comment

I haven't found a place that sells amazing rice balls like the ones you find in Japan so I was exited to try these. The employees are super friendly and you can watch them make the rice balls but these just aren't for me :( The flavor was good but it was way too much rice. I felt like I wasn't getting enough of a filling to rice ratio in every bite (and I love rice too!)

Cheap, quick and tasty! I love !!! They have a selection to choose from and you can just stop by and grab a bunch for a snack or lunch. Best yet it's in a Japanese grocery store so you can get more food if you want. I grabbed an eel and ate it in the plane when I got hungry and it absolved me of my hunger and it tasted great. The eel was soft and the rice was cooked perfectly.

A simple concept well-executed. Perfect place to pick up lunch or a snack. I'm so glad there is a place right in midtown where I can get tasty and well-priced onigiri along with other Japanese groceries inside Katagiri. Having purchased these a few times and tried several various types including the bomb (a large onigiri with three types of filling), my favorites are the Mentaiko (spicy seasoned cod roe), spicy salmon, and ume (pickled plum). I've been generally satisfied with the proportion of filling to rice, just the right amount to get some filling with each bite of rice. The little stand isn't manned all day--towards the end of the day they leave the remaining rice balls individually wrapped in plastic wrap on the counter with clear price lists so people can just pick up and check out. Better to go earlier in the day for the widest range of selection--by the end of the day some of the varieties are sold out.

This stuff was the perfect mid-day snack to fill us up but not too much before dinner. #37, the bomb, was so freaking delish- right amount of spicy, perfect amount of filling, but the real winner is how the seaweed is easy to bite through and keeps it's shape the whole time. The Japanese grocery store attached is really awesome too.
No comment

Our friend took us here on our way to catch a train at Grand Central (across the street) for a day trip during our NYC visit. Somewhat a musubi connoisseur, he proclaims the ones made here the best in the US, even better than Hawaii. Certainly more appetizing choices than Bachan's. The store is inside a Japanese grocery market. We had fun eating these fantastic rice balls with a variety of delicious fillings.

This is the best onigiri in Manhattan with the most variety as well. They must have like 40 different kinds of onigiri! Crazy! It was so good - my favorite is the cod roe, just like being back in Japan :).

As someone who always visits NYC on a budget I really thrive off of finding cheap eats and this is one of my favorite places to stop by. The place is located inside a small Japanese market that as well has great prices. The food is great and decently sized. Can't wait to come back!
Delicious onigiri.  I get the spicy tuna and it never disappoints.  Fast, friendly service.  Perfect for when you want a quick bite. The rice is perfectly cooked.  Definitely recommend.
No comment
No comment

I was craving for onigiri. I decided to check out this new place in the neighborhood (inside katagiri store). There were a lot of variety to choose from and i got "The Bomb" and the Salmon rice balls. After getting back to the office, I was excited to take a bite at this amazing looking rice ball. However, my excitement turned into a disappointment. The rice was plenty, the flavor of the rice was bland and the meat was barely any to be seen.  I just ate half and threw the rest away. Also. For the price, I would expect more ingredients in the rice ball. I would not recommend this place if you are craving for onigiri.

Love coming here for a quick lunch. Really affordable ($2-$3 each) and filling. Two pieces can probably fill most people up, but sometimes my eyes are bigger than my stomach and grab three. They also have brown rice options which aren't as traditional but still really good.

This is the only place I buy onigiri. The rice is imported from a specific rice farm in japan and polished in New York. So, it has a much sweeter and fresher taste than other rice. Some people complain about the amount of filling. But, onigiri are about the rice and it's the best in the city. I recommend the regular shiso, the plum with brown rice, the regular mustard leaf, the eel, and the fried oyster for fun.

I am a huge fan of this store and all the people who work there.  The service is friendly and warm, especially from Mika and Tiffany! I work next door and the variety of Japanese food is awesome  !! I highly suggest all the different onigiri and rice balls !!
Fresh ingredients and amazing rice (yes the rice matters as much as, if not more than the fish).  Prices are reasonable.  Come early as selections are limited and once they're gone, they're gone!
Picked up 5 onigiri yesterday.   They were great and very inexpensive.   That's a winning combo!

This is my go-to place for a filling and satisfying meal for under $10. My favorite onigiri are the grilled eel, katana (pickled mustard greens) and shrimp tempura. Most of the onigiri are around $2 with the exception of the eel and tempura ($3). I usually get two onigiri and a cup of the tofu miso soup for lunch and that gets me through the afternoon. Counter staff are always very friendly and quick. Love this place and so happy to have this as an option near my office in a Midtown east wasteland of overpriced chopped salad places, delis and bakeries.
No comment
I love this place. Best riceballs, they only come to the West coast near me once a year for a pop-up shop and I count the days!
worth the midtown lunch visit - rice triangles (onigiri balls), sushi and japanese grocery. kinda like cafe zaiya but also distinct. check out the fried chicken (karaage)

Loved visiting Omusubi Gonbei. Just a delicious as in NJ. The service was even better and more helpful. Definitely plan to return soon for rice balls, fried chicken and miso soup. Such a great, convenient location.
Gem of a place for quick tasty snack, groceries or a bowl of ramen.  Fried chicken is a winner!
Haven't tried the ramen yet but tasty fresh rice balls (eel is better than salmon) and the fried chicken looked pretty tasty too.

This is a fantastic addition to the NY food scene. Omusubi Gonbei prepares Japanese rice balls like my Mom's. Portions are ample, prices are low and there is a wide variety. Forget being on a low-carb diet. These are the best rice balls outside Tokyo (or maybe LA).

Thanks to NYTimes and Ligaya Mishan, I was able to try this on my recent visit to New York. I was NOT going to miss out. I ordered the Bomb, salmon, tuna, sardine and something else that I can't remember. They were all good. I even took what I could not eat back to Chicago. They survived the flight and the cab ride home. I purchased these items at around 10:30 am Eastern and ate most of it at 7:30 pm Central. They were still delicious!!!
No comment
No comment

I was sad to learn that the former neighborhood staple Sugarburg was closing. I didn't know why and it seemed that it happened out of no where! Regardless, time goes on and there's a new player in this space. H&H took the former Sugarburg and created a more seamless theme throughout the space. Part casual bar, part group hang spot, part semi-high end bar this spot seems to tick all the boxes for a great hang in the area. It's a different vibe than rock a rolla and union pool but it adds variety in the neighborhood with it's cleaner feel than the other bars in the area. There's a smaller beer selection but you get your money's worth with a six dollar large pint for lager. Staff here is friendly and there's ton of seating space within the bar. I'd definitely come here if you're looking for a more elevated bar experience with your friends!

Went here this weekend with some friends. We loved the beer shot deals they have all the time and the fries were delicious. Need to come back and try more of the menu. Special shout out for their rendition on the pickle back shot, the sauerback!

I was bummed when Sugarburg closed but now H&H has taken its place and it is fantastic! Inexpensive but really good drinks and the food from Dog Day Afternoon is fabulous. The Chicago dogs are so good but most impressive is the schnitzel which is thankfully pork and perfectly thinly fried - as it is supposed to be. Great location and easy to sit down and have a conversation.

This is my first ever yelp review and this place is the only reason I wanted to write one. We got two drinks, and order of the curry puffs, which we totally had to get another order of. The best staff, amazing ambiance, and the music really impressed me. Me and my friend felt totally welcomed and comfortable the whole time and decided it's an absolute return. The staff also brought out an order of chive dumplings on the house. Love you guys so much. Truly a sweet staff

Food was great, service was good and the atmosphere was amazing. Would definitely recommend and revisit this spot again. Friday night around 6pm for a group of 5 and we were seated right away without reservations.

Cool vibe, it's a nice social place to hang out and get some unique cocktails with some delightfully spicy food.
